name: Noise Residual Analysis
description: Examines high-frequency noise patterns by applying Wiener deconvolution. Real cameras produce characteristic sensor noise that varies across the image, while AI generates unnaturally uniform noise patterns.
mechanism:
The analysis process:

1. **Noise extraction**: Applies Wiener deconvolution filter to separate the noise component from image content.

2. **Local variance mapping**: Computes local noise variance across overlapping blocks to create a noise variance heatmap.

3. **Uniformity analysis**: Real camera noise varies due to sensor manufacturing imperfections (Photo Response Non-Uniformity). AI images lack this variation.

4. **Statistical profiling**: Analyzes noise distribution statistics (kurtosis, skewness) against known camera noise models.
parameters:
Filter: Wiener deconvolution, Window: 5x5
Block size: 16x16 with 50% overlap
Noise model: Gaussian + Poisson (heteroscedastic)
Metrics: local variance, kurtosis, skewness
accuracy: High - 82-92%. Most effective when comparing against known camera noise profiles.
source: Chen et al. (2008) - Determining Image Origin and Integrity Using Sensor Noise, IEEE TIFS
useCase: Detecting AI images through abnormally uniform noise patterns. Also used for camera source identification and tampering detection.
strengths:
• Robust against content manipulation
• Camera-specific noise is extremely difficult to forge
• Works across different image formats
• Can identify specific camera models
limitations:
• Effectiveness reduced by heavy denoising or compression
• Requires sufficient image resolution
• Some AI models now add synthetic noise to evade detection
• Social media compression degrades noise patterns

references.title: Chen, M. et al. (2008). Determining Image Origin and Integrity Using Sensor Noise. IEEE TIFS.
Lukas, J., Fridrich, J. & Goljan, M. (2006). Digital Camera Identification from Sensor Pattern Noise. IEEE TIFS.
Cozzolino, D. & Verdoliva, L. (2020). Noiseprint: A CNN-Based Camera Model Fingerprint. IEEE TIFS.
